8 different databases and datasets. Among which 2 are the Neonet datasets. We collect using the c14bazAAR and curated with NeoNet functions.
mapping table with period and culture coming from different datasest to be mapped to the Neonet main classes (10 classes, among which 4 are undefined and period transition).
Using










c14_aberrant_dates.tsv


With R functions coming from the C14bazaar R package and curated with the NeoNet R series of functions, we are gathering some 10,000 radiocarbon dates coming from 8 different datasets and databases.
We map these dates to the Neonet periods (here on the left class).
Then we remove duplicated dates and discard outliers (currently in process).
Some 4,000 dates are now available for the study.














c14_corrected_sitenames.geojson

 function neoent::neo_kss_create() 







pastclim R package to recreate the Koppen Climate classification (KCC) for past periods, currently from 8,000 BC to 5,000 cal BC (expressed here in cal BP)
KCC based on average temperature and precipitation patterns, dividing them into five main types: tropical, dry, temperate, continental, and polar. Each type is further subdivided based on seasonal precipitation and temperature patterns (30 classes).
The pastclim KCC current resolution is 30‚Äù = 0.5 degrees = c.¬†50 km. It uses the Beyer et al. 2020 dataset.

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean

MediansAdd Koppen Climate ClassesInterpolation


Most recent LM and most ancient EN date weighted medians (w-median) by site









For a given site, we select either the most recent LM date (ex: Monte Frignone) or simetrically the most ancient EN date (ex: Le Baratin)
Extract on the radiocarbon date weighted median from the Summed probability density (SPD)





























For a given site, we select either the most recent LM date (ex: Monte Frignone) or simetrically the most ancient EN date (ex: Le Baratin)
Extract on the radiocarbon date weighted median from the Summed probability density (SPD)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Near East (9,000 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Neolithic mostly on Csa (Temperate, dry summer, hot summer) and BSk (Temperate, dry summer, warm summer) climates
North and South Levant farmers separated by Dsa (Cold, dry summer, hot summer) climates: Mount Lebanon mountain range.
Cyprus early settlement: Klimonas (idf 55).

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Near East (8,500 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Small changes in the estimated area with Neolithic economy
Southward: new neolithic occupation in a BWh climate (Arid, desert, hot): Shkarat Msaied (idf 79).

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Near East (8,000 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Mount Lebanon range (Dsa) still acts as a frontier between North Levant and South Levant Neolithic
First Central Anatolia Plateau sites: Asikli H√∂y√ºk (idf 10), Kaletepe (idf 50) and Pinarbasi A (idf 68)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Near East (7,500 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Only one new occupation on the Central Anatolian Plateau, Musular (idf 63): barrier
In Southern Levant, close concentration of occupations in different climates: Csa, BSk, BWh and newly BSh (Arid, steppe, hot) and BWk (Arid, desert, cold).

Nahal Efe (idf 64), Hemar (idf 42)
Basta (idf 17)

Territorial expansion of mega-sites into different climates, ex: Basta (idf 17)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
üöß Central Anatolian barrier

7,300 BC7,000 BC6,700 BCObservations















































ca 7,500-7,000 BC, disconnection between Cyprus and the main land (Levant). End of the PPNB koine.
ca 6,700 BC, first South Western and Western Anatolian sites of Bademagaci (idf 16) and Cukurici (id 23) are temporally (w-medians) and spatially (distances) closer to Cretan sites of Delphinos (idf 25) and Knossos(idf 61) than BSk and Dsa Anatolian Plateau sites.
Confirms: Brami 20154.
ca 6,200 BC, aridification of the Central Anatolian Plateau (8.2 ky BP event)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
East Mediterranean (6,600 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Aegean sea and shore ‚Äòneolithised‚Äô before Northern Anatolia, and even before South central Anatolia.
Location of Yarimburgaz (idf 60,ca. 8,400 BC) and Cukurici (idf 14, ca. 6,800 BC) fits more with a maritime dispersal than a terrestrian one.
Earliest neolithic sites are those having pre-neolithic (i.e.¬†Mesolithic) obsidian coming from Melos: Maroulas (idf 35), Franchthi (idf 22) and Cyclops Cave (idf 15) with no climate data available but probably Csa. See Reingruber (2011)5.

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
East Mediterranean (6,200 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations































Greece mainland turns colder (8.2 ky BP event), for example: Dsa ‚Üí Dfb (Cold, no dry season, warm summer)
In South Balkans, concentration of dates in BSk climates (Sesklo, idf 52; Paliambela, idf 41); Anzabegovo, idf 41; etc. )
First Neolithic in Northern East Mediterranean (Ugurlu, idf 57, no climatic data) related to first Neolithic in Northwestern Anatolia: Barcin (idf 9), Aktopraklik (idf 2)
New Cfa climate (Temperate, no dry season, hot summer) with Mavropigi (idf 36), Lefkopetra (idf 33), Orfeas (idf 40)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
East Mediterranean (5,800 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Rapid expansion in the Southern Balkans (Csa and BSk). And slowdown of Neolithic expansion in Northern Balkans‚Äô expansion required adapting agriculture and stockbreeding systems to colder climates (Dfa, Dfb, ex: Porodin, idf 46). Confirms: Krau√ü et al.¬†20186, Ivanova et al.¬†20187.
Pioneer site in Dfa climate (Cold, no dry season, hot summer).
South of Italy (off the map) is reached, probably from Corfu: Sidari (idf 53)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Central Mediterranean (6,000 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































ca 6,300 BC, few years after Sidari (idf 147), neolithic features in Grotta del‚ÄôUzzo (idf 161, no climatic data) but possible Meso/Neo acculturation,
ca 6,000 BC, Pulo di Molfetta (idf 147, no climatic data), clear evidence of neolithisation (e.g.¬†build walls)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Central Mediterranean (5,700 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































5,800 BC, early Neolithic settlements (leapfrog) of Pollera, Arma dell‚ÄôAquila and Arene Candide in Liguria and Cfa climates.
5,800-5,600 BC: Rapid inland expansion Csa, for ex: La Marmotta (idf 69) and Rio Tana (idf 120), Central Italy. Confirms: Binder et al.¬†20228, Mazzucco et al.¬†20239
5,700 BC, SHM-1 (idf 128) in Tunisia in BSk climate, maybe related to Kronio (idf 128) in Sicily, dated ca 5,900 BC.

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Central Mediterranean (5,400 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































5,700-5,400 BC, in Italy, slowdown of the spread of Neolithic after its rapid expansion in South Italy. The change between mostly Csa (South of the Abruzzes) to Cfa (North of the Abruzzes) might be the reason.
5,700-5,400 BC, on both sides of the Ardriatic Sea (Italy and Croatia), linear gradient: maritime networks.
5,700-5,200 BC in Tyrrhenian and Ligurian Sea, development of the Cardial Filiestru-Basi-Pienza (Cardial FBP)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
West Mediterranean (5,600 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































Leapfrogs to Southern France and the Iberian Peninsula, with mostly settlements in (same) Csa climates, among others: Pont de Roque-Haute (idf 148, Southern France), Coves del Fem (idf 101, Northeastern Spain), Cabranosa (idf 31, South Portugal).
Fonbregoua in Cfb climate (Temperate, no dry season, warm summer) and Gazel in Cfa climate.

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
West Mediterranean (5,300 BC)

ClimatesSitesObservations
































5,900-5,300 BC, neolithisation of Southwestern Iberian Peninsula (Portugal).
Catalonian Neolithic faces different climates that slowdown the spread of the Neolithic (acclimatization): Csa, Cfa, Cfb.
At the opposite of Catalonia, Valencian area, with only the two main climates of Early Neolithic: Csa and BSk, favoring a faster diffusion.
Pioneer sites in Csb climate (Temperate, dry summer, warm summer) between 5,600 and 5,300 BC: Balma Margineda (idf 24, Andorra), Abri des Castelli (idf 3, Corsica) and, later, a cluster in the upper Ebro Basin: Tumul del Padro (idf 168), etc.

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text: End of the Mediterranean Neolithisation

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Climate evolution









Late foragers: Drop of the inhabited cold climates from 11k BP to 7k BP. In 9k BP newly occupied occupied Cold, dry summer, cold summer, possibly corresponding to the higher mountain range (Atlas, Alps, Pyrenees, etc.)
Early Farmers: 11k and 10k 2 main climates, continuous area: Fertile Crescent. Arid climates increases in 9k: arid margins (oasis). 8k and 7k: neolithisation of cold and temperated areas (Bulgaria, Southern Germany, etc.)
Comparison: LM occupied a larger diversity of ecozones. EF replace HG in cold climate over 4,000 years

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
section: Climates occupied by the Early Farmers
text:
Climates occupied by the Early Farmers

OverviewPioneer Neolithic sites












ca 10,000-9,500 BC, Near East BSk (Temperate, dry summer, warm summer), Csa (Temperate, dry summer, hot summer) and, more rarely, Dsa (Cold, dry summer, hot summer) climates.

ca 9,000-7,500 BC, Near East BWh climate (Arid, desert, hot), ie: arid margins. 

ca 8,000-7,500 BC, Near East (South Levant), BSh (Arid, steppe, hot), and BWk (Arid, desert, cold).

ca 6,500-6,000 BC, Balkans (between North and South), Cfa climate (Temperate, no dry season, hot summer).

ca 6,100-6,000 BC, Balkans, Dfb (Cold, no dry season, warm summer) = Proto-Sesklo Culture.

ca 6,100-6,000 BC, Northern Balkans and Central Europe, Dfa (Cold, no dry season, hot summer), outside the studied area.

ca 5,500-5,300 BC, Western Mediterranean, Csb climate (Temperate, dry summer, warm summer)

title: Climates during the Spread of Farming in the Mediterranean
text:
Footnotes


Late Foragers. Create an image in a portrait layout of: A Mediterranean coastal area, view from distance (bird eye), during the Late Mesolithic, with a temperate to cold and humid climate, showing an estuary river banks and a part of a marsh. The dominant colors in the image should be cool tones, such as blues and green, and the people should be dressed in furs suitable for cold to temperate climates (Koppen climate classes: Cfb and Dfa). Include only 5 characters: A women collecting sea shells and collecting fruits and wild seeds in cane baskets. A children collecting wild seeds in cane baskets. A man fishing with a vegetal net. A woman hunting ducks with a bow. A man skinning a fish. Include only these items: A vegetal net An arrow. Living wild animals should be distant from humans. The characters and animals in the image must be realistic. The faces of the people should be well-defined. The tools should be made of wood, flints and bones only. The image should have: No domestic animals. No ceramic potteries. No glass. No candle or wood fire. Do not include anything that I didn‚Äôt described
Early Farmers. The scene depicts a Mediterranean landscape set in a river valley of the inland Iberian Peninsula during the Neolithic period. The environment reflects the typical Mediterranean vegetation, including holm oaks, oak trees, and shrubs. The landscape shows a mosaic of forests and small cereal fields, with more emphasis on the dense forest. In the foreground, a group of five people is working in the fields, harvesting wheat using wooden and flint sickles. The group consists of three men and two women, all dressed in prehistoric brown wool and linen garments, appropriate for the period. In the background, there is a small flock of black goats and brown sheep, which are being watched over by an elderly woman and a child, both holding wooden staffs. The animals are enclosed within a small wooden pen located far from the cereal fields prompt@ChatGPT.
